trial_identification.studytitle: SUcceSS: SUrgery for Spinal Stenosis A randomised, placebo-controlled trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: SUcceSS: SUrgery for Spinal Stenosis A randomised, placebo-controlled trial to measure the effect of decompressive spinal surgery via laminectomy or laminotomy versus placebo surgery on pain and disability in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis.

interventions.interventions: a) Decompressive spinal surgery via laminectomy (which involves the removal of the lamina and spinous process of the vertebrae at the affected level with a high speed drill and/or bone punch, to relieve the pressure on the spinal nerve) or laminotomy (a small opening of the lamina above and below the spinal nerve is created with the high speed drill, leaving the remaining structure of the lamina intact) versus placebo surgery (same incision and muscle dissection as the active intervention but without bone removal). b) The use of the surgical procedures of laminotomy or laminectomy will be as per the surgeons standard procedures and will reflect real world practise. c) Spinal surgery will be performed in the operating theatres of the participating institutions and the operating time will vary from 2 to 4 hours d) Registered medical practitioners with no regulatory impediment to perform spinal decompression surgery in Australia will be invited to participate as study doctors
interventions.comparator: The placebo surgery arm will receive identical treatment to the active arm except that no bone removal will be performed during the surgery.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in walking ability: Global perceived improvement on walking ability will be measured on a scale of -5 to 5; where -5 represents vastly worse, 0 no change and 5 completely improved.
Change in function: The Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) questionnaire will be used to assess condition specific disability

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in disability: self-reported condition-specific disability will be measured using the walking section of the ODI questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in leg pain: average leg pain in the past 7 days will be assessed using 0-100 numerical rating scales.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in back pain: average back pain in the past 7 days will be assessed using 0-100 numerical rating scales
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Perceived recovery: perceived recovery will be measured using a seven-point Likert from completely recovered to worse than ever
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life: The Assessment of Quality of Life questionnaire (AQoL) will be used to assess quality of life
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hospital anxiety and depression scale (HADs) to capture both anxiety and depression.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life: The Assessment of Quality of Life questionnaire (AQoL) will be used to estimate QALYS for a cost-effectiveness analyses
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Overall satisfaction with surgery will be measured with the questions: How do you feel about the results of your surgery? with answers being Im satisfied, Im doubtful, Im dissatisfied

Expectation of satisfaction with surgical outcome in terms of pain and mobility will be measured as: How much pain relief would you expect from surgery? and How much improvement in your walking do you expect from surgery?

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Be 50 years of age or older; 2. Present with complaints of neurogenic claudication for at least 3 months. This will be assessed as: *pain and numbness below the buttock with or without back pain (if back pain is present, leg pain/discomfort > Back pain) that is aggravated by walking, and alleviated with lumbar flexion/sitting 3. Have narrowing of the lumbar spinal canal at one or two lumbar levels. Central narrowing defined as occlusion or near occlusion of CSF space at that level(s) on T2 weighted MRI or CT-Myelogram 4. Be medically suitable for single-or dual level spinal decompression surgery have not improved with non-surgical treatment
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Presence of malignant involvement of bone or Pagets disease of spine 2. Presence of lumbar instability defined as more than 4mm translation or 10 degrees of angular motion (at affected or adjacent level) between flexion and extension on upright lateral radiographs (to exclude patients who might need to undergo concurrent surgical fusion) 3. Previous spinal surgery at same level 4. Inadequate English to complete outcome measures 5. Cauda equina syndrome or motor deficits related to level of compression 6. Presence of significant scoliosis (Cobb angle >25 degress) or other spinal deformities 7. Presence of known or demonstrated peripheral vascular disease causing vascular claudication. 8. Grade 2 or greater spondylolisthesis

trial_design.concealment: Central randomisation by phone or web-based randomisation system.
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation will be by random permuted blocks and stratified by surgeons.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: A sample size of 80 per group (total of 160 participants) will achieve 90% power to detect a minimum clinically important difference of 15 points on leg pain, allowing for a loss to follow-up rate of 30% at three months. This sample will also allow us to detect an absolute difference of 20% in reoperation rates over 2 years of (the current reoperation rate for decompressive surgery is 7%). The Type I error probability associated with this null hypothesis is 0.05.

recruitment.hospital: Monash Medical Centre - Clayton campus - Clayton
Austin Health - Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital - Heidelberg West
Prince of Wales Private Hospital - Randwick
Newcastle Private Hospital - New Lambton Heights

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Surgical decompression for symptomatic spinal stenosis is justified primarily upon clinical experience, expert consensus and pathophysiological considerations, not high quality clinical trials results of past research have been significantly confounded by placebo effects of surgery. There is an urgent need to rigorously test decompressive surgery for spinal stenosis as the intervention is expensive and potentially harmful and is increasingly used reflecting our ageing community. The efficacy of surgical decompression, the most popular procedure for spinal stenosis, has not yet been proven, as it has never gone through high level of scientific scrutiny to establish its efficacy or safety beyond placebo effects. The SUcceSS trial aims to randomly allocate 160 participants with chronic, symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis to either decompressive surgery or placebo surgery to measure the efficacy of decompressive surgery on patients' outcomes with central spinal canal stenosis.
